paragraph.docTitle:
Metabolomic fingerprinting and genetic discrimination of four
Hypericum
taxa from Greece

document.paragraph:
Konstantina Zeliou a , Eirini-Maria Koui a , Charikleia Papaioannou b,c , Nikolaos Stavros Koulakiotis d , Gregoris Iatrou e , Anthony Tsarbopoulos d,f , Vassilis Papasotiropoulos c , Fotini N. Lamari
a, ∗

subSection.paragraph: Essential oil
Sesquiterpenes
Phloroglucinols
Flavonoids
Naphthodianthrones
Metabolomics
nrITS
Genetic analysis
Multivariate analysis

Hypericum perforatum
has plenty of uses in traditional medicine and is the source of top-selling herbal drugs and food supplements. The secondary metabolite chemistry for most of the nearly 500
Hypericum
taxa is still unknown, even though they are used interchangeably. In the present study, we characterized four
Hypericum
populations from Achaia, Greece , belonging to
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
,
H. perfoliatum
,
H. triquetrifolium
, and an uninvestigated taxon,
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
, in terms of their essential oils and polar bioactives in methanolic extracts via GC-MS, LC-HRMS, LC-DAD-MS, and HPLC-DAD. We also performed sequence analysis of nrITS to explore the genetic profile of these taxa and to examine whether their genotype is correlated to the metabolome. Sixty-three non-volatile compounds, phloroglucinols in their majority, and over one hundred (113) volatiles, mostly sesqui– and mono– terpenes, were detected. The concentration of the major polar constituents varied greatly among samples. In particular, phloroglucinols’ diversity and abundance in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was remarkable. The PCA and Biplot analysis revealed the contribution of each compound to the total chemodiversity and also revealed certain compounds that contribute to the discrimination of the samples. Sequence analysis of nrITS revealed different genetic profiles and markers which can be used for the identification of the four
Hypericum
taxa. The Mantel test showed a relatively strong correlation between the genetic profile and the volatile compounds and low with the main polar metabolites.

Hypericum perforatum
L. (family: Hypericaceae ), or else St John's wort, is a plant species with many traditional uses worldwide. It is also the source of top–selling herbal medicinal products mainly for mild–- to–moderate depression, a use which is supported by many clinical studies ( Ng et al., 2017 , European Medicines Agency, 2019 ). The hydroalcoholic extracts of
H. perforatum
aerial parts are rich in phenolic acid derivatives, xanthones, flavonoids (especially quercetin glycosides), proanthocyanidins, naphthodianthrones and phloroglucinols. An array of biological actions has been attributed to its metabolites, but it has been difficult to ascribe the biological and therapeutic effects of the extract to only one ingredient, and thus the extract is considered as the active principle ( Saddiqe et al., 2010 ).
H. perforatum
remains the most illustrative example of the potential herb–drug interactions, side–effects and the need for educated phytomedicine use and quality control. In this context, safe daily dose of hyperforin, the main phloroglucinol, has been set at < 1 mg (Chrubasik Hausmann et al., 2019), while hypericin, a naphthodianthrone that can be used in photodynamic therapy and in diagnosis, causes photosensitization as a side effect ( Jendzelovska et al., 2016 ). Interesting biological properties, mainly antimicrobial ( Crockett, 2010 ), have been ascribed to
Hypericum
essential oils, although the genus is generally poor in essential oils (oil yield <1%, w/ w).

About 500
Hypericum species
have been identified all over the world ( Crockett and Robson, 2011 ), whilst the Mediterranean basin is considered as one of the biodiversity hotspots for
Hypericum ( Nurk and Crockett, 2011 )
. Many of those taxa are used in traditional medicine interchangeably with
H. perforatum
and some are used in the St John's wort final products ( Booker et al., 2018 ; Scotti et al., 2019 ; Agapouda et al., 2019 ), but only the latter is listed in the Pharmacopoeias and in the monographs of both the European Medicines Agency and the World Health Organization. The secondary metabolites of different species vary, but, even within the same species, both the extract's and the essential oil's composition is not stable since it depends on different factors such as genotype, environmental conditions, post–harvest treatment and extraction conditions; all of them resulting to variation of its therapeutic efficacy ( Crockett and Robson, 2011 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Content (%) of the groups of volatile metabolites in the essential oils of the four
Hypericum
taxa (mean ± s.d.). HC–S: sesquiterpene hydrocarbons; OS: oxygenated sesquiterpenes; HC–O: monoterpene hydrocarbons; OM: oxygenated monoterpenes.

subSection.paragraph:
In this study,
H. perforatum ssp. veronense (Schrank) Ces.
(section Hypericum ),
H. perfoliatum
L. (section Drosocarpium ),
H. triquetrifolium Turra
(section Hypericum ), and
H. empetrifolium Willd.
ssp. e mpetrifolium (section Coridium ) were collected from Achaia, Greece , and their methanolic extracts and essential oils were analyzed using LC–MS and GC–MS, respectively. Since some main ingredients, like napthodianthrones and phloroglucinols, are very lipophilic and more soluble in organic alcohols, we chose methanol for the extraction, as earlier suggested ( Porzel et al., 2014 ). The major polar ingredients were quantified with a validated HPLC–DAD method ( Zeliou et al., 2017 ). Phytochemical data were subjected to multivariate analysis to reveal compositional differences among samples and the impact of each compound on their chemovariability. Thus, the metabolic profiles of
Hypericum
taxa growing in the wild in North Peloponnesus were recorded for the first time, including the globally uninvestigated subspecies
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
. Genetic analysis using the nrITS sequences was performed for the authentication of plant material and the discrimination among the different taxa and to examine if chemical variability and genetic diversity correlate with each other.

Hypericum
essential oils are complex chemical mixtures of a wide variety of volatiles ( Crockett, 2010 ; Bertoli et al., 2011 ); they include aliphatic hydrocarbons, the monoterpenes α – and β –pinene, and the sesquiterpenes (
E
)– β –caryophyllene and caryophyllene oxide. Although there are several studies regarding the essential oils’ composition of
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
(former:
H. perforatum ssp. angustifolium
),
H. perfoliatum
,
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. empetrifolium
( Couladis et al., 2001 ; Bertoli et al., 2003 ; Petrakis et al., 2005 ; Touafek et al., 2005 ; Hosni et al., 2007 , 2008 , 2011 ; Maggi et al., 2010 ), this is the first investigation, to our knowledge, of the essential oil composition of
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
.

The total essential oil yield was approximately 0.48%, 0.27%, 0.26%, and 0.62% v/w for
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, H. perfoliatum , H. triquetrifolium ,
and
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
, respectively. Sesquiterpenes dominated in the composition of the essential oils from all taxa ( Fig. 1 ). The content of sesquiterpene hydrocarbons (the most abundant group of compounds) ranged from 50.1% in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
to 61.3% in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
. The oxygenated sesquiterpenes made up the second most abundant group (3.6–18.9%) in all taxa except
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
; in the latter, monoterpene hydrocarbons had a strong presence (35.3%). Monoterpene concentration was also high (over 10.0%) in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, but not in the other two taxa ( Fig. 1 ). Alkane content was higher in
H. perfoliatum
and
H. triquetrifolium
(11.3 and 11.7% respectively) than in the rest. The finding of high levels of alkanes is not unexpected in
Hypericum
genus, neither in the two aforementioned taxa ( Couladis et al., 2001 ; Bertoli et al., 2003 , 2011 ; Hosni et al., 2008 ).

In total, one hundred thirteen (113) compounds were identified in the essential oils of the four examined taxa, and only thirty–five were in common ( Table 1 ). The majority (100 out of 113) had been reported previously in
H. perforatum
,
H. perfoliatum
,
H. triquetrifolium
or
H. empetrifolium
species, or in other
Hypericum species
( Petrakis et al., 2005 ; Radusiene et al., 2005 ; Hajdari et al., 2014 ; Bardhi et al., 2015 ; Sajjadi et al., 2015 ; Ghiasvand et al., 2016 ). Among them, (
E
)– β –caryophyllene, an FDA–approved food additive that interacts with cannabinoid CB2 receptors ( Varga et al., 2018 ), was one of the most abundant compounds in all taxa (6.57%–27.90%).

In the essential oil of
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, α – and β – selinene had almost the same concentration (about 15% each), while the other main ingredients (
E
)– β –caryophyllene, α –pinene and germacrene–D ranged from 5 to 10%. The above composition cannot justify the categorization in any of the chemotypes of
H. perforatum
( Bertoli et al., 2011 ; Morshedloo et al., 2015 ), however the three latter compounds have been found repeatedly in high amounts in
H. perforatum ( Bertoli et al., 2011 )
. Similar percentages of germacrene D and (
E
)– β –caryophyllene were determined in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
from Central Italy (7.8–9.7% and 6.0–9.2%, respectively) ( Maggi et al., 2010 ). Only in a few cases selinene isomers have been reported to be among the most abundant compounds, e.g. in
H. perforatum
from Turkey (4.1–19.6%, respectively) ( Cirak et al., 2010 ). Furthermore, 2–methyl–octane which in many cases is among the most abundant volatiles in
H. perforatum
( Mathis and Ourisson, 1964 ; Bertoli et al., 2011 ), herein constitutes only about 1.2% of total volatiles.

subSection.paragraph:
Except for γ –muurolene (8.52%), the concentration of the other compounds in the essential oil of
H. perfoliatum
was lower than 8.0%; only δ –cadinene, γ –cadinene, ( E )– β –caryophyllene, germacrene D and n–undecane were in concentrations higher than 4.0%. Those data coupled with the high number of 68 compounds (>0.2%) show the great chemodiversity of
H. perfoliatum
essential oil. Remarkably, the two most abundant compounds herein ( γ –muurolene and δ –cadinene) have not been reported previously in such high concentrations in
H. perfoliatum
( Couladis et al., 2001 ; Petrakis et al., 2005 ; Hosni et al., 2008 ). However, several compounds that have been considered as main volatiles in the taxon, such as n –nonane, thymol, 4,5–dimethyl–ethylphenol, and τ –cadinol ( Couladis et al., 2001 ; Touafek et al., 2005 ; Petrakis et al., 2005 ), were not detected or quantified herein.

Many compounds in traces were recorded in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
, as well; three compounds, (
E
)– β –farnesene, α –pinene, and (
E
)– β –caryophyllene, accounted for over 58.0% of the total peak area. The main (29.5%) volatile, (
E
)– β –farnesene, has not been mentioned previously in
H. empetrifolium
, but only in other
Hypericum species
, e.g.
H. olympicum
L. in Serbia ( Gudzic et al., 2001 ). The abundance of α –pinene, β –pinene, D–limonene, and ( E )– β –caryophyllene in our study of
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was in accordance with a previous report on
H. empetrifolium ( Petrakis et al., 2005 )
.

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Metabolomic fingerprinting and quantitative analysis of methanolic extracts

subSection.paragraph:
The total yield of methanol extraction was 15.8%, 14.8%, 25.1%, and 19.9% w/w for
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, H. perfoliatum , H. triquetrifolium ,
and
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
, respectively.

subSection.paragraph:
We used different analytical techniques to study the phytochemical composition of the dry
Hypericum
methanolic extracts. In all cases, liquid chromatography was used for the separation of the metabolites on a C–18 column. Analysis with Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography (UPLC) coupled to a hybrid quadrupole time–of–flight mass spectrometer (QTOF) equipped with an electrospray ionization (ESI) interface, enabled the identification of compounds based on the mass accuracy of the molecular ion and the fragmentation pattern. Additionally, analysis with UHPLC coupled to a diode array detector (DAD) and a quadrupole ion trap MS analyzer equipped with ESI enabled the recording of the UV–vis spectra along with the mass spectra, which assisted the identification in several cases. Finally, quantification of the major ingredients was performed using a previously validated HPLC–DAD method ( Zeliou et al., 2017 ). In the four
Hypericum
taxa, we identified three caffeoylquinic acids, seventeen flavonoids [i.e. a myricetin hexoside (flavonone), quercetin and seven of its glycosides (flavonols), biapigenin and amentoflavone (biflavones), astilbin (flavanonol), and five flavanols], four xanthones, one spiroterpene, four naphthodianthrones (pseudohypericin, hypericin and their proto precursors), and over 30 phloroglucinols (or phloroglucinol derivatives) ( Table 2 ).

Among the many hydroxycinnamic acid derivatives, caffeoylquinic acids are the most abundant and common secondary metabolites that have been detected in
Hypericum
genus ( Sarrou et al., 2018 ). They have been correlated to the wound healing, antioxidant and antidepressant activity of various preparations of
Hypericum species.
Herein, 3– O –caffeoylquinic acid ( 3 ) was in high concentration in all samples ( Table 3 ), while two other caffeoylquinic acids ( 1 and 6 ) were detected, as well. The concentration of phenolic acids (CQAs) in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
( 83.3 mg g −1 D.W.) was at least 150% higher than in the other three taxa ( Fig. 2 ).

Flavonoids were abundant in all taxa. In particular, the presence of two flavanol monomers (peaks 4 and 7 ), two flavanol dimers and one flavanol trimer ( 2 , 5 , and 8 , respectively) is congruent with many previous studies in
Hypericum
( Ploss et al., 2001 ; Farag and Wessjohann, 2012 ; Cirak et al., 2014 , 2015 ; Sarrou et al., 2018 ). Flavanol concentration was the highest in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
( 10.4 mg g −1 D.W.) and the lowest in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
( 0.8 mg g −1 D.W.) ( Fig. 2 , Table 3 ). A myricetin hexoside ( 9 ), which has been reported in the genus ( Porzel et al., 2014 ), was detected and quantified herein in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
and
H. perfoliatum
. In accordance with previous studies ( Tatsis et al., 2007 ; Crockett and Robson, 2011 ; Porzel et al., 2014 ; Sarrou et al., 2018 ), seven quercetin glycosides ( 10 , 11 , 12 , 14 , 15 , 16, and 18 ) and the aglycon of quercetin ( 19 ) were determined. Quercetin–3–acetyl–galactoside ( 16 ) and quercetin–3–
O
–acetyl–arabinofuranoside ( 18 ), previously detected in the genus ( Jurgenliemk and Nahrstedt, 2002 ; Tatsis et al., 2007 ), were determined in
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
. Taxifolin–3–rhamnoside (astilbin) ( 13 ) was detected in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, as previously ( Porzel et al., 2014 ). Biflavonoids, i.e. 3,8″–biapigenin ( 20 ) and amentoflavone (3′,8″–biapigenin) ( 21 ), were present in all taxa in agreement with previous studies ( Crockett and Robson, 2011 ). Overall, the concentration of flavones–biflavonoids varied slightly among
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
,
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. perfoliatum
(82.6, 80.7 and 73.7 mg g −1 D.W., respectively), but in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was 30% lower ( 48.3 mg g −1 D.W.) ( Fig. 2 ).

Quantitatively, the most abundant flavonoid was hyperoside in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
and
H. perfoliatum
, rutin in
H. triquetrifolium
, and a quercetin pentoside in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
( Table 3 ). It is worth mentioning that only traces of rutin were detected in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
( Table 3 ). Traces of rutin have also been detected in
H. perforatum
by Zeliou et al. (2017) ; Napoli et al. (2018) ; Booker et al. (2018) , while many other studies showed that rutin is abundant ( Rusalepp et al., 2017 ; Sarrou et al., 2018 ). Thus, it seems that rutin shows a great intraspecies variability.

subSection.paragraph:
Naphthodianthrones are present almost exclusively in
Hypericum
and their accumulation is an important chemotaxonomic criterion ( Kitanov, 2001 ), while they have significant biological properties. In fact, hypericin has demonstrated antimicrobial, antiviral and anti–- tumor activity ( Jendzelovska et al., 2016 ). In the present study, pseudohypericin ( 27 ) and hypericin ( 42 ) were detected in all taxa in agreement with previous studies ( Tatsis et al., 2007 ; Ayan and Cirak, 2008 ; Alali et al., 2009 ; Alali and Tawaha, 2009 ; Hosni et al., 2010 ). However, they were below the quantification limit in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
in accordance with previous studies on
H. empetrifolium
( Kitanov, 2001 ; Alali et al., 2009 ; Tawaha et al., 2010 ). Naphthodianthrone concentration is correlated to the presence of dark glands ( Crockett and Robson, 2011 ; Cirak et al., 2016 ). Herein, their concentration was higher in those sections that present dark glands in more than two organs, i.e. Hypericum (
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
and
H. triquetrifolium
with 5.7 and 2.1 mg g −1 D.W., respectively) and Drosocarpium (
H. perfoliatum
with 6.3 mg g −1 D.W.) ( Crockett and Robson, 2011 ). Accordingly, the precursor molecules, protopseudohypericin ( 26 ) and protohypericin ( 38 ), were detected in all examined taxa except for
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
, but they could be quantified only in
H. triquetrifolium
( Table 3 ).

Another group of compounds with pharmacological importance –antimicrobial, antidepressant, antinociceptive and cytotoxic in cell lines according to Bridi et al. (2018) – is phloroglucinols (phloroglucinol and their alkyl– or prenyl– derivatives). The most well–known of them is hyperforin and it has been studied mainly for its anti–depressant potential ( Bridi et al., 2018 ; Chrubasik Hausmann et al., 2019). We observed remarkable diversity of phloroglucinols among the taxa; eight different phloroglucinolic compounds were detected in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
, six in
H. perfoliatum
, nine in
H. triquetrifolium
, and ten in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
( Table 2 ). The quantification of phloroglucinols was not achieved except for empetrikarinol B ( 36 ), empetriferdinan A ( 39 ) and 1–[5,7–dihydroxy–2–methyl–2–(4–methylpent–3–enyl)chroman–6–yl]–2–methylbutan–1–one ( 41 ) in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
and hyperforin ( 60 ) in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
.
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
had the highest number and concentration of phloroglucinols, while
H. perfoliatum
had the lowest number and traces of them ( Fig. 2 ). No phloroglucinol was common among all examined taxa.

All phloroglucinols in
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
( 45 , 47 , 48 , 49 , 51 , 59 , 60 , and 61 ) were previously detected in
H. perforatum
( Fuzzati et al., 2001 ; Porzel et al., 2014 ; Guo et al., 2017 ). In addition, previously detected phloroglucinols in
H. perfoliatum ( Benkiki et al., 2003 )
,
H. triquetrifolium
( Mitsopoulou et al., 2015 ; Volkov, 2018 ) and
H. empetrifolium
( Schmidt et al., 2012a , 2012b ) were identified herein ( Table 2 ). There are several phloroglucinols ( 31 , 32 , 37 , 40 , 43 , 46 , 58 ), with molecular formulas identical to those observed in other taxa ( Tatsis et al., 2007 ; Hashida et al., 2008 ; Mamemura et al., 2011 ; Shiu et al., 2012 ) or to previously detected phloroglucinols that have not been characterized yet ( Porzel et al., 2014 ).

Xanthones have been previously isolated from
Hypericum
genus ( Cardona et al., 1990 ; Wu et al., 1998 ; Tanaka et al., 2009 ; Crockett and Robson, 2011 ). Herein, four xanthones ( 17 , 22 , 23 , and 25 ) were detected but could not be unambiguously identified. Another group of compounds in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was that of spiroterpenoids, i.e. hyperireflexolide A or B ( 24 ) that has been isolated from
H. reflexum
L. f. ( Cardona et al., 1993 ). Finally, an unknown compound ( 34 ) which has been previously detected in the genus ( Porzel et al., 2014 ) was detected in
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
.

There are many inconclusive data about the role of each substance category in the therapeutic efficacy of
Hypericum
extracts and
Hypericum
extract as a whole is considered the bioactive principle. Porzel et al. (2014) proposed that the bioactivity of
Hypericum
taxa may be predicted by metabolic profiling; they particularly stressed the links of high naphthodianthrone content and cytotoxicity. Thus, the high content of naphthodianthrones in
H. perfoliatum
might suggest anticancer, anti-microbial and anti-viral efficacy. Moreover,
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
and
H. triquetrifolium
should be investigated as an alternative to
H. perforatum
for the treatment of cognitive diseases since they are rich in phloroglucinols. However, further research on the chemical identity of phloroglucinols is needed and attention should be paid on their plausible pharmacokinetic interactions, since hyperforin has such effects. The concentration of total phenolics did not vary greatly among the examined samples. In particular,
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
is the richest in chlorogenic acid which might impart stronger antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, or antimicrobial properties to the extract ( Naveed et al., 2018 ). Altogether, further research is necessary due to the multiple biological activities of each compound and the synergy/antagonism phenomena in the extracts.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. PCA biplots (after Varimax rotation) of major metabolites of essential oils (A and B) and methanolic extracts (C and D) obtained from
Hypericum
samples. HPV:
Hypericum perforatum ssp. veronense , HP
:
Hypericum perforatum, HT
:
Hypericum triquetrifolium , HEE
:
Hypericum empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
.

document.paragraph:
The phytochemical data were subjected to principal component analysis (PCA) and biplots were also produced to determine the association of the chemical compounds with the
Hypericum
genotypes and their impact on samples’ chemovariation ( Fig. 3 ).

Τhe % peak areas of 47 volatile compounds (>1.0%) were subjected to PCA ( Fig. 3 Α and B). 99.7% of total variability is explained by the first three principal components. PC 1, PC 2 and PC 3 explained 53.2%, 24.5% and 22.0% of the existing variance, respectively. Based on the biplot analysis,
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
samples are associated with terpinolene, β –pinene and E–β –farnesene;
H. perfoliatum
with β –copaene, α –cadinol and tetradecanoic acid;
H. triquetrifolium
with α –muurolene, α –amorphene, α –humulene, tetracosane and trans - squalene. Finally, 2–methyloctane and tetradecanol were associated with
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
samples. These results add to those by Bertoli et al. (2018) who also identified specific volatiles as discrimiminating markers of
Hypericum species.

The concentration of the 24 most abundant ingredients of the methanolic extract were also subjected to PCA, and a 99.6% of total variability of data is explained by the first three components ( Fig. 3C and D ), whereas PC 1, PC 2 and PC 3 explained 61.2%, 20.7%, and 17.7%, respectively. Based on the biplot analysis,
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
samples are distinguished by phloroglucinol derivatives (empetrikarinol B, empetriferdinan A, and compound 41) and caffeoylquinic acids (CQA II and CQ3A);
H. triquetrifolium
by rutin and compound 44 (a phloroglucinol);
H. perforatum ssp. veronence
by flavanol III, astilbin, hyperforin, isoquercitrin, and quercetin–3– O –acetyl–arabinofuranoside, and finally
H. perfoliatum
by myricetin hexoside and quercetin pentoside. Previous studies have shown that hypericin, quercetin, rutin, and chlorogenic acid were mainly responsible for variation within
Hypericum
genus ( Bozin et al., 2013 ; Cirak et al., 2016 ; Rusalepp et al., 2017 ). Our results suggest that the majority of the above–mentioned metabolites along with phloroglucinols (that are quite unique for each taxon), have a strong impact on chemovariation.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. Genetic data analysis and genetic relationships

subSection.paragraph:
Manual editing of the sequences obtained, resulted to a consensus of 719–725 bp for the entire ITS region. Following multiple sequence alignment, the total length of the nucleotide sequences studied, including the gaps, was 726 bp. Of the 726 bp, 652 sites were conserved among the four taxa, 73 were variable, whereas 59 parsimony informative. Genetic divergence ranged from 2.4% (between
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
) to 7.2% (between
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
and
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
) ( Table S1 ).

The phylogenetic reconstruction obtained by NJ, UPGMA and MP methods using the nrITS region was overall in agreement with that observed in other studies of
Hypericum species
( Meseguer et al., 2013 ; Nurk et al., 2013 ). All the dendrograms exhibited similar topologies, therefore only the UPGMA reconstruction is presented here ( Fig. 4 ).
Hypericum
individuals were clustered into four distinct, strongly supported clades, which correspond to their respective species. A close phylogenetic relationship was present between
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
. These two taxa were phylogenetically related to
H. perfoliatum
, while
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was the most distant among the taxa studied.

Following sequence alignment several SNPs (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms) were revealed, that can be used to identify and discriminate among the four taxa. For example, a nucleotide substitution from adenine ( A ) to guanine (G) at the alignment position 52 can be used for the identification of
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
. Moreover,
H. perfoliatum
is discriminated by a single nucleotide substitution from cytosine (C) to thymine (T) at the alignment position 79, and
H. triquetrifolium
by a single nucleotide substitution from guanine (G) to thymine (T) at the alignment position 93. Finally,
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
is identified by a single nucleotide substitution from cytosine (C) to guanine (G) at the alignment position 245. When these sequences were aligned with nrITS sequences derived from Greek endemic taxa already deposited in GenBank [
Hypericum amblyocalyx
( KC709390 ),
Hypericum athoum
( AY555846 , HE653412 – HE653414 ),
Hypericum delphicum
( AY555845 , HE653450 – HE653452 , FJ694197 , AY573009 ) and
Hypericum taygeteum
( HE653638 )], three unique nucleotide changes at alignment positions 103, 259 and 474 respectively (supplementary Figure S1 ) were revealed for the identification of the economically important species
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
.

Finally, the Mantel test showed strong correlation between the genetic and the essential oil data, (R = 0.645, P <0.05, 99 iterations), and low between the genetic data and the polar metabolites in methanolic extracts (R = 0.267, P <0.05, 99 iterations). This finding complies with previous studies which showed a positive correlation between the main non–volatile secondary metabolites (e.g. chlorogenic acid, rutin, hyperoside, quercitrin, pseudohypericin, hypericin and hyperforin) and the genotype of different
Hypericum
taxa ( Smelcerovic et al., 2006 ; Aziz et al., 2006 ). So far, there are no data in the literature regarding the correlation of the essential oil composition with genetic diversity in
Hypericum species.

This is the first study combining metabolomic fingerprinting of over 170 volatile and non–volatile compounds and genetic analysis of the four
Hypericum
taxa from Greece . The four different populations (each from a different taxon) had plenty of differences in their chemical content. Regarding essential oil composition, all samples were rich in sesquiterpene hydrocarbons and oxygenated ones, and ( E )– β –caryophyllene was among the three most abundant volatiles in all examined taxa. All methanolic extracts contained phenolic acid derivatives, proanthocyanidins, flavonoids, naphthodianthrones and a high number of phloroglucinols. The diversity of phloroglucinols was remarkable and quite unique for each sample, since over 30 were detected in total. None of them was common among the samples studied, implying their possible contribution to species identification and authentication. Indeed, the PCA and biplot analysis demonstrated that the samples could be associated with specific volatile and polar constituents, including specific phloroglucinols. In quantitative terms,
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
was the richest in flavonoids (especially hyperoside, isoquercitrin and flavonols);
H. perfoliatum
and
H. triquetrifolium
followed with high amounts of rutin, whereas
H. empetrifolium ssp. empetrifolium
was the richest in caffeoylquinic acids and the poorest in naphthodianthrones. The quantitative phytochemical profiling could be used as a guide for their possible medicinal uses.

Genetic analysis revealed a significant level of polymorphism among the four taxa studied. Differences in base composition of the nrITS region could be used as diagnostics for the discrimination of the taxa. Additionally, the Mantel test showed a significant correlation between the genetic profile and the essential oil composition and a significant but low correlation with the polar metabolites. Our results contribute to the potential valorization of other less known
Hypericum
taxa by providing information on their chemovariability and also potential markers for their genetic and chemical discrimination which could be useful for taxonomic and authentication purposes.

Aerial parts from flowered and apparently healthy plants of
Hypericum perforatum ssp. veronense (Scrank) A. Fröhl
(section Hypericum ),
Hypericum perfoliatum
L. (sect. Drosocarpium ),
Hypericum empetrifolium Willd. ssp. empetrifolium
(sect. Coridium ),
Hypericum triquetrifolium
(sect. Hypericum ) (Family: Hypericaceae ) were sampled in May–July 2015 , and identified by Prof. Gregorios Iatrou, University of Patras. Voucher specimens (14,306, 14,307, 14,308 and 14,309, respectively) are deposited at the Botanical Museum of the University of Patras (UPA). Aerial parts of about 30 individuals from each population (one per taxon) were collected from the great area of Patras, Peloponnesus , Greece ( 38°29′15.9″N ; 21°79′24.1″E− 38°32′17.9″N ; 21°87′27.2″E). The samples were dried in an airy and shaded room for two weeks. Dried samples were transferred to the laboratory facilities for further processing preserved at room temperature and in darkness until used. The pooled apical 25–30 cm of each taxon was used for the methanolic extraction and the isolation of essential oils.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. UPGMA dendrogram of the
Hypericum
taxa studied revealed four distinct strongly supported clades. A close phylogenetic relationship was observed between
H. triquetrifolium
and
H. perforatum ssp. veronense
. These two taxa were phylogenetically related to

, while

was the most distant. Bootstrap values were calculated from 1000 resamplings of the alignment data.

subSection.paragraph: Methanol extracts were prepared with maceration of at least 10 g of pooled dried material. For each g of dried material 2 mL of methanol was used and the extraction was performed in a water bath at 40 °C, at dark for 24 h. The extract was filtered and in the residual plant material, methanol was added (the same volume as in the first extraction step) and set under magnetic stirring for 24 h at room temperature at dark. The latter procedure was repeated twice. The extracts were concentrated under vacuum at 35 °C and then lyophilized (Freezone 6, Labconco, MO, U.S.A. ). The procedure was performed twice for each taxon. Dry extracts were kept at −20 °C until use.

Compounds were identified by UPLC–ESI MS and MS/MS analyses on a QTOF Premier (Waters, Milford, MA ,
USA) hybrid quadrupole time–of–flight mass spectrometer, equipped with electrospray ionization (ESI) interface and operated in both negative and positive ion modes. The separation was performed on a ΒΕΗ C18 column (100 × 2.1 mm , i. d.: 1.7 μm; Waters, USA) kept at 40 °C by the Acquity UPLC system (Waters, USA), while the flow rate was set at 0.4 mL min −1 and the injection volume was set at 10 μL and sample temperature was kept at 10 °C. The UPLC elution system consisted of a combination of gradient and isocratic steps of (A) aqueous formic acid 0.1% and (B) acetonitrile (0 min, 5% B; 7 min, 50% B; 9 min, 80% B; 16 min, 100% B; 16–20 min, 100% B; 22 min, 100% B; 22–25 min, 5% B). Total elution time was 25 min. Full–scan mass spectra were acquired in centroid mode in the mass range of 85–1200 amu. The ESI interface operated in both negative and positive ion mode at 1.5 kV. Full–scan mass spectra were acquired in centroid mode in the mass range of 85–1200 amu. Nitrogen was used both as desolvation and cone gas and was set at 650 and 50 L h −1 , respectively, whereas argon was the collision gas. The TOF analyzer was operated in the V optics mode affording a resolution of 10,000, and leucine encephalin (500 pg L −1 solution; m/z 554.2615) continuously infused at a 2 μL min −1 using the built–in syringe pump of the instrument to ensure high mass measurement accuracy
. The sensitivity of analysis was evaluated at the collision energy values of 2 , 10, 20, 40 , 60 and 100 eV, and the first three values have been selected as the optimum values for analysis. The MassLynx V 4.1 (SCN 703) software (Waters) was used for instrument control and data acquisition. Data processing was performed by Mass Lynx V 4.1 and MZmine2 V 2.16 (
Katajamaa et al., 2006
; Pluskal et al., 2010 ).

Mass spectra combined with UV–vis spectra of compounds detected in methanolic extract were obtained by LC–DAD–MS analysis. UHPLC system was consisted by an UltiMate 3000 liquid chromatograph (Dionex, ThermoScientific). Injection volume was set at 10 μL. The separation was performed on an Acclaim RSLC 120 C18 (120 Å, 2.1 mm × 150 mm , 2.2 μm, Thermo Scientific) with flow rate at 0.1 mL min −1 . The UHPLC elution system consisted of a combination of gradient and isocratic steps of (A) aqueous formic acid 0.1% and (B) acetonitrile (0 min, 5% B; 40 min, 100% B; 40–50 min, 100% B). The UHPLC system was coupled to a Dionex Ultimate DAD detector and was further coupled to a quadrupole ion–trap AmaZon SL mass spectrometer equipped with ESI interface (Bruker Daltonics). The data have been processed by Data Analysis V 4.2 (Bruker Daltonics) . UV detection was set at 220, 300 , 350 and 590 nm , and mass detection was set
100– 2000 m
/z.

Six HPLC reference standards [chlorogenic acid (3–
O
–caffeoylquinic acid, ≥99%), hyperoside (quercetin–3–
O
–galactoside, ≥98%), isoquercitrin (quercetin–3–
O
–glycoside, ≥99%) quercetin (≥99%), and hypericin (≥95%)] were supplied from Extrasynthese (Genay Cedex, France ).

Quantification
of caffeoylquinic acids was performed at 300 nm , based on chlorogenic acid standard curve; of rutin, hyperoside, isoquercetin, and quercetin at 350 nm based on their standard curves; of proanthocyanidins and phloroglucinols at 270 nm , based on the rutin standard curve; of the rest of flavonoids also at 350 nm based on rutin standard curve; and of naphthodianthrones at 590 nm based on hypericin standard curve
(
Zeliou et al ., 2017
).

Analysis was carried out in an Agilent 6890N GC apparatus coupled to an Agilent 5975 B mass spectrometer with a non–polar column HP–5MS ( 30 m × 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm film thickness) using electron impact (70 eV) ionization mode. Helium was used as a carrier gas, the flow rate for the HP–5MS column was 1 mL min −1 ; the injected volume was 1 μL in splitless mode. Injector temperature was set at 280 °C and source temp at 230 °C. Initial oven temperature was 60 °C, which was then ramped at 4 °C min −1 to 113 °C, at 0.5 °C min −1 to 138 °C, and finally at 8 °C min −1 to 280 °C. The retention indices of volatile compounds were calculated using retention time data from a series of alkane standards (C8–C40) under the same chromatographic conditions. Compounds were identified by matching mass spectra and RI (retention indices) with Adams (2012) , library entries (NIST/EPA/NIH Mass Spectral Library, Version 2.0d; NIST, Gaithersburg, MD), NIST Chemistry WebBook, and literature data. Only compounds with peak area higher than 0.20% are presented.

Genomic DNA was extracted from dried leaf samples from three individuals of each of the
Hypericum
taxa studied. For the DNA extraction two different methods were tested, the CTAB (cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide) method modified from Doyle and Doyle (1990) , including 2% PVP (polyvinylpyrolidone) and the ISOLATE II Plant DNA Kit (Bioline, United Kingdom ) following the manufacturer's protocol. Twenty (20) mg of plant tissue were used per extraction. Both methods provided similar results in the quality and quantity of the extracted DNA. Quantification and quality assessment of the purified DNA were performed spectrophotometrically and by agarose gel electrophoresis. The samples were stored at –20 °C until used.

Due to the degradation of the template DNA, Internal Transcribed Spacer 1 (ITS1), and Internal Transcribed Spacer 2 (ITS2) regions, including 5.8S , were amplified separately using the primer combinations of ITS– A with ITS–C and ITS– B with ITS–D ( Blattner, 1999 ) ( Table S2 ), which were designed to amplify the entire ITS region.

PCR amplifications were carried out in 50 μL reactions containing 20 ng template DNA, 0.4 μM forward and reverse primers, 1.5 mM MgCl 2 , 0.2 mM dNTPs, 1 × Taq buffer (10 × KAPA Taq Buffer w/ loading dye) and 1 U of KAPA Taq DNA Polymerase (Kapa Biosystems). PCR conditions were carried out in a BIORAD C1000 Touch Thermal Cycler (BioRad) as follows. An initial denaturation at 95 °C for 5 min was followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 95 °C for 30 s, annealing at 55.5 °C for 30 s and extension at 72 °C for 1 min, with a final extension at 72 °C for 10 min.

In order to verify the PCR products, 5 μL of each PCR product were electrophoresed in 2% agarose gels, with a 100 bp NEB DNA ladder (New England BioLabs Inc.) and photographed on a Gel Doc XR + System (BioRad). Gel images were captured and analyzed using the Image Lab™ software. The results showed that for each one of the two primer pairs, the size of the PCR products corresponded well to the PCR product sizes given by Blattner (1999) . Amplified products were purified using the Macherey – Nagel Nucleospin Gel and PCR Clean–up Kit and sequencing was performed. The sequences obtained, have been deposited in GenBank under accession numbers MN036437 – MN036448 .

ITS1, 5.8S and ITS2 sequences from each template were manually edited and combined in single consensus sequences using Seqman II sequence analysis software (DNASTAR Inc.). Clustal Omega multiple sequence alignment program ( Mc William et al., 2013 ) with the default parameters was used for the multiple sequence alignment of the combined ITS1– 5.8S –ITS2 fragments. MEGA version 7 ( Kumar et al., 2016 ) was used to estimate the genetic distances (Kimura two parameters model) and for the construction of a NJ (Neighbor–Joining) as well as an UPGMA (unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean) dendrogram (1000 bootstrap replicates). Maximum Parsimony analysis was also performed, using PAUP *ver.4.0 beta 10 ( Swofford, 2003 ).

MEGA version 7 ( Kumar et al., 2016 ) was also used for the examination of the ITS1– 5.8S –ITS2 fragments for the presence of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) that could discriminate the species.
None.

The funding agency had no involvement in study design; in the collection, analysis and interpretation of data; in the writing of the report; and in the decision to submit the article for publication.
